results.title: Playtime [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Specta Films, Rene Silvera and Jacques Tati
results.brief_description: The third of Tati’s films to feature the gangling form of Monsieur Hulot, “Playtime” is a surreal, comic vision of mankind’s battle against the overwhelming depersonalisation of modern city life. Filmed upon one of the most ambitious and imaginative sets ever to grace the screen, Tati’s cinematic magnum opus took three years and a reported one million pounds to shoot. The result is a startling triumph acclaimed by the international media as Tati’s finest work. Also available on VHS [302002].

results.title: Play misty for me [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Malpaso Company, Robert Daley and Clint Eastwood
results.brief_description: In this contemporary thriller, Clint Eastwood plays the popular California disc jockey, Dave Garland. On his radio show he repeatedly receives a phone request for “Play Misty for Me”, from a feminine voice. Garland meets the owner of the mysterious voice, Evelyn Draper, at a night spot he frequents. Unsuspecting, he takes her home with him and there the terror begins. Stars Jessica Walter, Donna Mills and John Larch. Photographed by Bruce Surtees. Screenplay by Jo Heims and Dean Riesner. “Misty” composed and performed by Erroll Garner.

results.title: Play it again Sam
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Rollins-Joffe Productions, Arthur P. Jacobs and Herbert Ross
results.brief_description: Woody Allen plays Alan, a fanatical movie buff whose wife has just left him. He has an outrageous recurring hallucination of Humphrey Bogart coaching him on how to make it with the ladies. His married friends, Dick and Linda fix him up with several eligible young ladies, but his self-confidence is low and it makes for a series of hilarious tragi-comic scenes where he fails dismally at every attempt he makes to impress. Eventually he discovers that there has been one woman all along who is right for him - his best friend’s wife! The final scene is a brilliant spoof of “Casablanca”, complete with trench coats and heavy fog. Also stars Diane Keaton as Linda.

results.title: Planet of the apes
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, APJAC Productions, Mort Abrahams, Arthur P. Jacobs and Franklin J. Schaffner
results.brief_description: Charlton Heston and two other astronauts come out of deep hibernation to find that their ship has crashed. Escaping with little more than clothes, they find that they have landed on a planet where men are pre-lingual and uncivilized, while apes have learned speech and technology and use the primitive humans for experimentation and sport. Taylor (Heston) is captured and taken to the city of the apes after damaging his throat so that he is silent and cannot communicate with them. But with the help of a benevolent chimpanzee scientist (Roddy McDowall), Taylor escapes their leathery clutches only to be confronted by a chilling fate. Interesting Note: During breaks in filming, actors made up as different ape species tended to hang out together—-apes with apes, orangutans with orangutans, chimps with chimps. It wasn’t required, it just naturally happened. Includes 25 minutes “Making Of” program.

results.title: Planes, trains and automobiles
results.brief_description: It’s Thanksgiving and Neal Page (Steve Martin) is looking forward to spending some quality time with the family. While on the flight home, Neal is seated next to obnoxious shower curtain ring salesman Del Griffith (John Candy). When a snow storm causes their plane to be rerouted, the two are reluctantly united by their misfortune. Thus begins a disastrous chain of events that transcends all forms of public transport and threatens to make Neal miss Thanksgiving all together.

results.title: Plan 9 from outer space = Grave robbers from outer space
results.creator_credit: Reynolds Pictures and Edward Wood Jr
results.brief_description: The local authorities join forces with the military to ward off an invasion of flying saucers. Undeterred, the aliens continue their attempt to conquer Earth by resurrecting corpses from a San Fernando cemetery. “Plan 9 from outer space” has been described as the worst film ever made. This dubious honour has led to the cult status and notoriety the film enjoys to this day, proving that any publicity is good publicity. Those who have seen Tim Burton’s homage, “Ed Wood”(312025), will enjoy seeing this original masterpiece. Bela Lugosi played the definitive vampire as Count Dracula in Tod Browning’s 1931 classic horror (314058). In “Plan 9”, he revives his ghoulish persona in this, his final screen role.

results.title: Place Vendome [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Les Films Alain Sarde, TF1 Films productions, Les Films de L'Etang, Christine Gozlan and Nicole Garcia
results.brief_description: Part thriller, part character study, ‘Place Vendome’ is set against the backdrop of the rarefied and secretive world of the diamond traders of Paris’ Place Vendome. Marianne (Catherine Deneuve) is married to Vincent (Bernard Fresson), a diamond trader. Chronically alcoholic for years, she is brought out of her stupor with the news of her husband’s suicide and revelations about the state of his business. Vincent has left seven diamonds of dubious provenance for Marianne. This is enough for Marianne to decide to sober up, revive her shattered career as a diamond expert and try to sell the gems. She finds herself thrown into a web of intrigue involving a former lover (Jacques Dutronc), the same who once destroyed her good name by compromising her into a smuggling operation. Catherine Deneuve was awarded the Best Actress Prize at the 1998 Venice Film Festival (Mostra). Cast also includes Jean-Pierre Bacri and Emmanuelle Seigner. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Pistol opera
results.creator_credit: DENTSU, Eisei Gekijo Company, Ogura Jimusyo, Shochiku, Television Tokyo Channel 12, Katashima Ikki, Satoru Ogura and Seijun Suzuki
results.brief_description: In the late 60s, Seijun Suzuki developed a cult following with his re-envisioning of B-grade Japanese gangster flicks, defying the tropes of the genre with his desultory approach to narrative and imaginative stylistics. Here, freed of convention, Suzuki explores the possibilities of his art with astoundingly colourful and inventive vignettes that track the movements of Miyuki Minazuki, (also known as stray cat) a beautiful female assassin who dresses in black (with heels) and is determined to be number one amid her peers. This quest requires her to face down her many formidable foes and do battle, depicted in a series of extraordinarily beautiful tableaux. Stray cat must also deal with her lover and boss, a mysterious woman with whom she shares an explosive relationship. Absurdist and dreamily hallucinatory filmmaking, investigates shadowy, irrational aspects of desire. Somewhere between a remake and a sequel to Suzuki’s own cult movie “Branded to Kill” (1967). Cast includes Makiko Esumi, Sayoko Yamaguchi, Kan Hanae, Masatoshi Nagase, Mikijiro Hira, Kirin Kiki.

results.title: Pink Floyd: Pulse
results.creator_credit: Picture Music International (PMI), Pink Floyd (1987) Ltd, Lana Topham and David Mallet
results.brief_description: Recorded live at Earls Court, London on October 20th, 1994. This is classic Pink Floyd performing some of their best known music including “Learning to fly”, “Another brick in the wall”, “Money”, “Us and them”, and “Comfortably numb”. Features David Gilmour, Nick Mason and Richard Wright with Sam Brown, Claudia Fontaine, Durga McBroom on backing vocals, Jon Carin on keyboard and vocals, Dick Parry on saxophone, Tim Renwick on guitars and vocals and Gary Wallis on percussion.
